title: Brendan Rodgers is a future Man Utd boss
text:

Brendan Rodgers is leading Leicester City back into the Champions League – and he is a future Manchester United manager.

Don’t get me wrong: When I say Rodgers is destined for high office at United, I am NOT saying Ole Gunnar Solskjaer should be sacked.

I am not in favour of football’s hiring-and-firing culture, and Solskjaer deserves time.

But I’ve been so impressed by the job Rodgers has done since he took over at the King Power eight months ago that I’m convinced Leicester can finish in the top four.

The team he has built is so well-drilled, and so easy on the eye, that I would fancy them to beat Claudio Ranieri’s 5,000-1 title-winning miracles of 2016.

(Image: PA)

And Rodgers’ track record suggests not only that he was right to leave Celtic earlier this year - but his next job should be at one of Europe’s top clubs.

Look at the stats and you’ll find Leicester’s lofty place in the table is no fluke.

Since Rodgers took over they have taken 34 points from 18 games, scoring 32 goals and conceding 15 in return.

Only Liverpool (51 points and 48 goals scored) and Manchester City (49 points, 48 goals) have a better record over the last 18 games either side of the summer.

And Rodgers has procured that record despite losing £80 million Harry Maguire to Manchester United – although Caglar Soyuncu, who hardly got a look-in last season, has performed so well you can barely spot the difference.

(Image: REUTERS)

There is so much to admire about this Leicester side it’s difficult to find any weaknesses.

Scouts and recruitment departments at the so-called Big Six must be looking at midfielders James Maddison and Youri Tielemans and wondering how on earth they were not picked up on the radar.

Those two cost just Leicester a shade over £60million between them – but they must be worth £80m each already.

What were the big clubs looking at when those two were on the market?

Rodgers is getting the best out of Jamie Vardy – 10 goals in 10 home games – again. Defenders are looking nervously over their shoulder for a ball round the corner from Tielemans or a through the channels from the outstanding Ben Chilwell.

Throw in the exciting potential of Harvey Barnes, Ricardo Pereira’s goals from full-back and a fantastic goalkeeper, Kasper Schmeichel, and Rodgers has assembled a remarkably strong hand.

(Image: Getty Images)

In 2015-16, when Leicester won the title, I didn’t really believe they were going to do it until the last four or five weeks of the season.

But I’m not going to wait so long to nail my colours to the mast this time.

I think Leicester will finish above United, and I believe they will finish in the top four.

Rodgers has proved his near-miss with the title at Liverpool in 2014 was no flash in the pan, and he would have completed the ‘Treble Treble’ at Celtic if he had stayed to the end of last season.

In short, he is the real deal as a manager.

I repeat: I am not advocating that Solskjaer is removed from his job at Old Trafford. He deserves to be given more scope to rebuild that squad.

But when the time is right, and United are looking for their next manager to play fluent, progressive football, Rodgers – not Mauricio Pochettino, who was first choice when Jose Mourinho was sacked last season – would be my pick.
description: The former Liverpool manager is revolutionising Leicester and could take the reigns at Old Trafford in the future
